theText: On the 23rd May, theAIB SERVICES. Civil Aviation, upon notice1. What annual subsidy has Guinea Airways been paid for the' Adelaide-Darwin weekly mail service each year since the servico begun in February, 1927, to date? 2. On what basis is the subsidy allowed? 3. What is the distance of the air-mail route from Adelaide to Darwin? 4. What is the subsidy paid to Australian National Airways for the air-mail service between Melbourne and Perth, thrice weekly? 5. On what basis is the subsidy paid? 0. What is the distance of the air-mail route from Melbourne to Perth? honourable member's questions are as allowances, follows:1. The Adelaide-Darwin service was inaugurated by Guinea Airways in February, 1937, and was then operated as an unsubsidized service. From the 2nd August, 1938, the service was subsidized and during the remainder of the year the company was paid £19,933 subsidy. The subsidy paid in 1939 was £44,411, and under the present twelve mouths' agreement the annua] subsidy is £30,820. 2. The annual amount of subsidy paid tor nn air service is the amount by which the estimated operating costs, including the allowance for profit, exceed the estimated net revenue nnd is determined by negotiation between the airline operator and a committee specially appointed for this purpose. In these negotiations the following factors are taken into account:(a) The amount of capital required by the airline operator. (6) The reasonable operating costs, including a margin for profit of fl per cent, of the value of the assets in the press that a senior surgeon serving employed by the company in its subsidized services at the commencement of the contract. Out of this 6 per cent, allowance, the comtralian Imperial Force in Palestine? If'such pany is required to pay all dividends, taxation and provide also for any general reserves not covered in the operating costs. (o) The estimated net revenue. 3. 1,065 miles. 4 and 5. Since tlie 29th January, 1940, Australian National Airways has not operated its network of air services, which includes the Perth-'Melbour.ne service, uuder the subsidy arrangement applying to other subsidized services. It is proposed that tlie company be paid on a Tb -mile basis in respect of the gross weight of mail carried over all its services. Pending completion of negotiations with the company, .payment .of subsidy at the rate of £30,000 per annum is being made to tbe company for all of its services operating from Melbourne to Hobart, Sydney, Adelaide .and Perth. 11. 1.809 miles. Army, upon notice1. Is the fact that tlie Government recently introduced a different basis for the payment of allowances to dependants of members of the Australian Imperial Force to be taken us an admission that the previous formula had been an inequitable one? 2. If so, w i ll he take action to have such liberalized payments made retrospective to the date of enlistment in each case? honourable member's questions arc as follows:1, In connection with claims for dependant's practical experience in eases submitted to the District Finance Officers showed that in many instances the claims could not be satisfactorily dealt with under the conditions approved last November. Modifications were recently approved providing for a basis which it is considered will prove more satisfactory. A f u l l statement on the subject was issued and published in the press on the 23rd May. 2. The new conditions are treated as operating from the 6th October, 1939. honourable member for Lang( Mr Mulcahy) asked the following question, -without notice :Has the attention of the Minister for the Army been drawn to a statement published with the Australian Imperial Force in Palestine has requested some people in Sydney to send hospital equipment for use by the Aussupplies are needed, w ill thp Minister take steps to despatch them as soon as possible? I am now in a position to inform the honourable member that the 1st Australian General Hospital left Sydney without certain items of its medical equipment which could not be obtained in time. This equipment was forwarded subsequently and there is now no shortage in that unit of medical supplies for present requirements. The 2nd Australian General Hospital, now also abroad, is of double the .size of the 1st Australian General Hospital and has complete supplies which will be available to the other unit if -Esquired/

speaker: Mr Street
theText: On the 28th May thefor the Army, upon notice1. Is, (a) vaccination, OT (b) inoculation, compulsory for members of the Home Defenco Forces of the United Kingdom? 2. If the answer is " H o " in cither case, what evil results have followed from . the absence of compulsion? 3. If the answer is " Yes" in either case, why is compulsion deemed to be a military necessity in respect of the Australian Militia, as stated in the Minister's answer to the question of the honourable member for Bourke of the 8th May? honourable member's questions are as follows:1. (a) Vaccination is compulsory for all recruits for the Regular Army in Great Britain; (6) No information is available as to whether inoculation is compulsory or not at present in the Home Forces. 2. Because of tbe lack of inoculation there was an extensive epidemic of typhoid fever in England in the last four years when inoculation was not compulsory. There were somo cases ot typhoid fever in the British Army in Home Stations during the year 1938-39, the proportion being 1 per 10,000 men serving. 3. Vaccination is not compulsory for the Militia Forces in Australia. Inoculation is compulsory because typhoid fever is prevalent iu the civilian population in the vicinity of camps, and carriers of the disease arc common in any community. When men are congregated together in camps there is an appreciable risk of epidemics of typhoid fever. If one man in a camp is not protected by inoculation he may endanger the Uvea of others in the camp. MR. ESSINGTON LEWI S. Army, upon notice1. Is the Mr Essington LewiB who has been appointed Director-General of Munitions Supply identical with the Mr Essington Lewis who owns a large property near Tallarook, Victoria? 2. Is it a fact that, last October, this property was selected by the Defence authorities as the most suitable one for certain military training operations? 3. For what reason was the taking over' of this property by' the Defence authorities not proceeded with?4. Why was an adjoining and less suitable property commandeered? 5. Did Mr Lewis object to a water supply pipe -for military purposes traversing liis property? 0. If so, is it considered that Mr Lewis, in 60 objecting, acted in the best interests of the Commonwealth? 7. Is the Government satisfied that Mr fawis, in his capacity as Director-General of the interests of the Broken Hill Proprietary Company Limited? honourable member's questions are as follows:1. Yes. 2. The property of Mr Lewis was selected as one suitable for use for military purposes. 3. On further consideration it was seen -that this property had been highly developed. considerable expenditure having been incurred nn pasture improvement and the like. Asn consequence, the compensation payable for military occupation, and the claims for resultant damage, could have been considerably greater. 4. A neighbouring .property was then (elected on which the pastures' had not been improved to anything like tbe same extent as those of Mr Lewis. Furthermore, the residence on the property was not habited and military occupation therefore involved no disturbance. 5. Mr Lewis did make representations in this connection, but subsequently granted permission for the line tu be constructed over portion of his property. 0. I am quite sure Mr Lewis would at all times wish to serve the interests of th« Commonwealth. .7. Yes.
